loans.use: to purchase rice, beans, and lemonade drinks to resell, so as to earn more

loans.name: Ibikorwa Group

texts.fr:
Elie  fait partie du groupe  Ibikorwa   et  habite à Bubanza. Il  a 39 ans et est marié à Médiatrice. Ensemble ils ont  3 enfants âgés  de  7 mois  à  7 ans,dont 1 étudie.

Il fait le commerce de riz, haricot,... à revendre cuits dans son restaurant depuis 5 ans. 

C’est son premier   crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il  obtient, il va  augmenter son capital et acheter  80 kg de haricot et un bidon de 20litres  d’huile de palme. 

Dans les prochaines  années, il voudrait  construire des maisons de location.
texts.en:
Elie is part of the group Ibikorwa and lives in Bubanza. He is 39 years old and married to Médiatrice. Together they have three children,  from 7 months to 7 years old, of whom one is a student. 

Elie has been doing commerce for five years in rice, beans, … to resell cooked in his restaurant. 

This is his third Turame loan. With the KIVA loan he is obtaining, he is going to increase his capital and purchase 80 kg of beans and a 20-liter container of palm oil. 

In the coming years, he would like to build a house to rent out.

loans.use: to purchase beans and palm oil for his restaurant

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 35 years old and lives in the town of Ibanda in the Mbarara region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 2 years, Stella has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes to sell, and will help Stella to generate greater profits to get more money and sell new clothes and will be able pay school fees for her child. Stella hopes that in the future she will be able to get more money to expand the business and own another boutique. 

Stella is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Stella who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ana Milagro

texts.es: Ana de 34 años de edad vive en casa propia con sus cinco hijos y su esposo ella se dedica a la venta de refrescos dese hace 3 años, su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, posee mucha clientela por ser un producto muy vendible y a buen precio, con lo que obtiene de su trabajo y con ayuda de su esposo logran solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, Ana está solicitando un crédito para la compra de refrescos por mayor para tener más surtido su negocio y así obtener mejores ganancias y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Ana is 34 years old. She lives in her own house with her five children and her husband. She has worked for three years selling soft drinks. Her business is located in the place where she lives. She has a lot of customers, because her product is popular and her prices are good. With the earnings from her work, and with her husband's help, she is able to cover some of the household expenses. Ana is requesting a loan to buy soft drinks on a wholesale basis, so that she will have more inventory for her business. and she can obtain better earnings and give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks on a wholesale basis.

loans.name: Aniceta

texts.es: Aniceta esta agradecida por el crédito y le fue my bien, ella continua dedicándose a la agricultura, ganadería, artesanía, venta de verduras y frutas y crianza de animales menores y sigue teniendo el pequeño puesto de venta alrededor de uno de los mercados de la ciudad de Huancarani, ella está contenta por participar del banco comunal de la Asociación Arariwa porque es una persona responsable y alegre y en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar mercadería como verduras y frutas.
texts.en: Aniceta is grateful for the loan, and things have been going very well for her. She continues to dedicate herself to farming, raising livestock, handicrafts, selling fruits and vegetables, and raising small animals. She continues to operate a small sales stand near one of the markets of the city of Huancarani. She is happy about participating in the communal bank program of the Arariwa Association, because she is a cheerful and responsible person. On this occasion, she needs the loan to buy merchandise such as vegetables and fruits.

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Farogat

texts.ru: Фарогат жизнерадостная и целеустремленная женщина. Ей 41 года. Она замужем и на воспитании имеет одну не совершеннолетнюю дочь. Фарогат выросла в семье рабочего. Она с детства мечтала стать учительницей. После окончания средней школы она поступила в Педагогический университет. Фарогат с 1990 года работает в средней школе учительницей младших классов. Фарогат работает с удовольствием. Она очень любит свою работу. Ее муж является парикмахером. Они имеют маленький доход. Фарогат хочет купить стиральную машинку, телевизор и микроволновку. Она обратилась за займом в сумму 4000 сомони для покупки стиральной машинки, телевизора и микроволновки. Она очень хочет, чтобы ее дочь смотрела телевизор и была информировано новыми событиями. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en:
Farogat is a lively and goal-oriented woman. She is 41 years old, married and is raising one teenage daughter. Farogat grew up in a worker's family but since her childhood she dreamed of becoming a teacher. After finishing high school she attended the Pedagogical University and has been working as an elementary school teacher since 1990. Faragot loves her work and enjoys teaching children. Farogat's husband works as a barber and their family's income is modest. 

Farogat wants to buy a new washing machine, TV and microwave. She has turned to Kiva for a loan of 4000 somoni to purchase these household items. She especially wants a TV, so that her daughter can watch it and be informed about current events. Farogat awaits your kindness.

loans.use: to buy a washing machine, TV set and microwave for her household

loans.name: Muhogo Group

texts.en:
DANIELY is in his early 20s and single. He has been selling electronic money transfers for one year now. He works from 8am to 10pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Daniely's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania Ltd. He will use this loan to increase the working capital of his business. He dreams of becoming an international business man.

Daniely will share this loan with his loan group, Muhogo, which has nine members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase the working capital of his business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a married woman. She has one child who goes to school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. For the past three years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling second-hand clothes for both men and women. She cites stiff competition as her major challenge in the business. Fatuma is requesting a loan of KES 20,000 to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married woman with two children, all of whom go to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past 10 years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets to sell

loans.name: Tujenge Group

texts.fr: Shamamba est une commerçante et membre d’une association d’affaires « TUJENGE », femme mariée, âgée  de 25 ans et mère de quatre enfants sous  dont deux étudient et deux sont encore gosses. Elle est vendeuse   de friperie depuis six ans. Elle a sollicité un crédit auprès de Hekima. Elle va acheter 2 ballots de friperie pour accroitre son entreprise. Elle avait commencé avec de fonds propre reçu de son mari. Dans l’avenir, elle rêve devenir une grande femme d’affaires et acheter une voiture. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour son soutien aux femmes entrepreneurs exclues  du système bancaire classique.
texts.en:
Shamamba is a merchant and a member of the business association "TUJENGE". She is a married woman, 25 years old, and the mother of four children (two students and two little ones). Shamamba has been a vendor of secondhand clothing for six years. She has requested a loan from Hekima to purchase 2 bales of used clothing to grow her enterprise. She had started off with her own funds from her husband. 

For the future, she dreams of becoming a great businesswoman and to purchase a car. Thus, she thanks Hekima for its support of women entrepreneurs excluded from the traditional banking system.

loans.use: to purchase 2 bales of secondhand clothing

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dorine's Group

texts.en:
Dorine lives with her 2 children in a house made of mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof in Musanyi village in Kenya, Kenya. The community of Musanyi village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of Vihiga Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Musanyi’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Musanyi, 60 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Dorine has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Eglay, Simon, Ronald, and Florence.

Musanyi village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Dorine believes that the dispenser will kill germs. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Dorine’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Beatrice's Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is 32 years old, has 4 children, and lives in Gamgoi village in Vihiga, Kenya. Gamgoi village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a river, stream, or other flowing water source. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Beatrice and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Beatrice works as a subsistence/peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Beatrice and other promoters in her community (including Janet and Phanike) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Beatrice will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Beatrice wants to be a promoter because she is loved by community, and she believes that the dispenser will save lives.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Beatrice’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Together Group

texts.en:
These four ladies are part of a group called ‘Together’ and are starting their fifth loan cycle with ID Ghana and second with Kiva. The group is made up of four members and is represented by Matilda. Members engage in various business activities which include product sales like fruit, drinks, biscuits, Milo, and milk. 

The loan they are requesting will benefit small business owner Matilda (standing third from left in the photo). She joined 'Together' two years ago at the invitation of a friend who is a member of the group. Currently, she has a business selling different kinds of drinks from a small bar at her residence. She says she started this business on the advice of her parents. She buys the drinks from the wholesale depot and resells to customers. She is requesting this loan to increase her merchandise and to purchase more drinks to sell. This type of work allows her to generate an income to support her family since she is married with three children. 

When asked what she likes about ID Ghana, she responded that she likes working with the group and the savings opportunities with the organization. The group needs a total loan amount of 4,600 GHS to increase their stock.

loans.use: to increase her merchandise and purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Ahlam's Group

texts.en:
Ahlam is a 48-year-old Iraqi woman with a small, home based sewing business activity. She is married and a mother of four children.

With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Ahlam is one of the many Iraqi women who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family. Although she learned to sew a long time ago, she started to use her sewing skills as an income generating activity two yeas ago.  

She is now taking a group loan to buy a new sewing machine to increase the quality of her work and a small generator to allow her to work during the many hours of the day when her area is without electricity. 

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group.

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine and a small generator

loans.name: Khorn's Group

texts.en: Khorn, 27, is a mother of two little children who are under six years old. Rice farming is the family's main source of income. Fishing is another source of income. Khorn and her husband have been doing these businesses for around seven years. This is Khorn's second loan with VisionFund Cambodia and she is now leading two female members. Khorn will use her loan portion to spend on her dry season rice farm, for example, buying rice seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and land cultivating. She hopes this loan will allow her to grow more better quality rice so that she can sell the crops for a higher price to better support her family.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizer and pesticides and pay for land cultivation

loans.name: Bofa

texts.en: Bofa is 21 years old and lives in the area of Kakata Town, the capital city of Margibi County, which is the highest-producing rubber plantation area of Liberia. Bofa and her boyfriend live together, along with their two children who are two and five years old. Both children live at home and attend school. Bofa is a high school graduate. For the past two years, she has been operating a little shop where she sells charcoal. She started this business with a loan from her mother. She enjoys her business because she has a lot of customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal by the bag for her business and she plans to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal by the bag to sell

loans.name: Monicah's Group

texts.en:
In Givavei village in Vihiga, Kenya, Monicah has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. She is a 47-year-old farmer who has 6 children.

Givavei village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an undeveloped source. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Monicah and the 10 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Monicah has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her people stay healthy. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Solomon, Felistus, Everlyn, and Josephine. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Monicah’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Susan's Group

texts.en:
Susan lives in a home with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof in Kaptaisi village in Vihiga, Kenya. She is 22 years old and has a 2-year-old daughter. The community of Kaptaisi village collects their drinking water from an unprotected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of Vihiga Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Kaptaisi’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Kaptaisi, 20 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Susan has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Janet, Beatrice and Aggrey.

Kaptaisi village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Susan believes that the dispenser will prevent her neighbors from falling sick from water-borne diseases. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Susan’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Shohista

texts.ru:
Шохиста жительница села района Кубадиён. Ей 28 лет. Шохиста замужняя женщина. Она много лет работает в школе учительницей. Она любит детей и свою работу. Шохиста умная и энергичная женщина. Она успевает работать и в школе и дома. Дома у себя Шохиста работает на грядке, она выращивает сельскохозяйственные культуры. 
   Шохиста хочет начать бизнес по откорму и продаже скота. Она уверенна, что и в этой области деятельности она преуспеет. Шохиста просит кредит, чтобы купить пару голов крупнорогатого скота. Она надеется, что они станут основоположниками в ее бизнесе. Шохиста будет кормить своих скотов в течение определенного времени и продаст их с наценкой на скотном рынке. Шохиста верит, что ее обязательно ждет удача, и она начнет свой бизнес. Шохиста надеется, что ей помогут. Шохиста ждет Вашей помощи!
texts.en: Shohista is a village resident in the Qubadiyon region. She is 28 years old, married and has been working as a teacher for years. Shohista loves children and her work. She is a smart and energetic woman and manages to work both at school and at home, where she grows produce for sale. Shohista wants to also start fattening and selling cattle. She is certain that she will be successful in this venture. Shohista is requesting a loan to buy a few heads of cattle to start. She hopes that these animals will be the foundation of her livestock business. Shohista will be fattening the cattle for a time and then selling them at the livestock market for a better price. She hopes that you will be able to help her start a new business.

loans.use: to purchase a few heads of cattle and start her cattle feeding business

loans.name: Luis Alonso

texts.es: A sus 62 años de edad  Luis trabaja muy duro para poder ganarse la vida. Con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado adecuar una pequeña tienda en su lugar de residencia la cual es su principal fuente de ingresos. Tiene muchos clientes que demandan sus productos ya que en su tienda se encuentran productos de primera necesidad a muy buenos precios. Con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado construir su vivienda la cual necesita algunas mejoras ya que con el tiempo el techo se encuentra en mal estado. Por falta de ingresos no ha logrado reparar el  techo por lo que solicita este crédito a FUSAI para invertir en la compra de lámina galvanizada y madera para poner nuevamente el techo de su vivienda y así poder contar con mayor seguridad.
texts.en: At age 62, Luis works very hard to be able to earn a living.  He has managed to set up a small store in his home with great effort, and it’s his main source of income.  He has many customers who want his products and he has many primary needs products at good prices in his store.  He has managed to build his house, but it needs some improvements, since the roof has deteriorated over time.  He has not been able to repair it due to insufficient income, so he is asking for a loan through FUSAI, so he can buy galvanized metal and lumber to install a new roof and be safer.

loans.use: to replace his roof.

loans.name: Charming Group

texts.en:
Joni is the featured borrower of Charming group. She got together with the other group members to acquire a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua because they have always been best friends since they left their hometown in the Philippines. They left the Philippines to work as housekeepers to improve and develop their families' living.


Joni is the first lady standing at the far left side of picture, wearing a black jacket. She is a 46-year-old widowed mother of one child. She works as a housekeeper to provide her only child with the best education and living, since she is his sole breadwinner.


Joni is acquiring a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to send the money to her child back there in Philippines to cover his needs.


As for the other group members, Finah is the second from the left, Melencia is the second from the right with a grey jeans jacket, and Ofelia is the first on the right.

loans.use: to send money to her child back in the Philippines to cover his needs.

loans.name: Tuvuke Group

texts.en:
Gloria, who is in her late 30s, is married with four children who are still going to school  She has been selling hardware since 2010.  She works from 6 am to 8 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Gloria's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to buy more stock of hardware to resell.  She dreams of having a very big hardware store.

Gloria will share this loan with her loan group, Tuvuke, which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more hardware to resell.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is asking for a loan because she believes that with it, she will improve her business.

Her previous loan enabled her to open a hair dressing shop. In addition, she operates a retail shop

She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profit and help her family cover their personal expenses. The loan of KSHS 50,000 she is requesting will help her to purchase cooking oil, sugar, soap, and cereal for her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, sugar, soap, and cereal to sell

loans.name: Everlyne's Group

texts.en:
In Liavola village in Vihiga, Kenya, diploma-holder Everlyne has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Everlyne is friendly and an active member of the village prayer group with 7 children.  Everlyne lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof.

Liavola village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink.  Everlyne and the 40 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Everlyne has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because it makes her community grow and she wants to help the community because she believes chlorine will improve their health and as a result less hospital expenses will be incurred. There are also two other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Mercy and Hezron.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that  Everlyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en:
Joyce lives in a home with mud walls, sand or dirt floor, and an iron roof in Wanalo village in Vihiga, Kenya with her 3 children. The community of Wanalo village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of Vihiga Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Wanalo’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Wanalo, 30 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Joyce has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Catherine, Tabitha, Violet and Terry.

Wanalo village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Joyce believes that the dispenser will help the community's hygiene. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Joyce’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Kenga Development Association Group

texts.en:
Pulikeria is 46 and is married with 4 children aged 13, 15, 17 and 19. She pays all the tuition for the children since her husband cannot help enough. She is a farmer and also operates an agricultural produce store at Kenga Central, a business she started in 2000.

Pulikeria has approached UGAFODE for a loan through her group, Kenga Development Association, to buy more produce now that the harvest season has started. She hopes that she will buy cheaply at the moment and later sell at a high price. She wiil be able to repay the loan after the sale of the produce.

Her main challenges are sub-standard produce sold to her by suppliers and poor transportation for transporting her produce.

loans.use: To buy agricultural produce

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en: Eugenia is taking a loan of 600 USD to improve her business. She runs a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store such as eggs, noodles, cigarettes, coffee, sugar, salt, milk and oil. She opened her kiosk a year ago with her own working capital of 100 USD.  She is a hard working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: To buy eggs, noodles, cigarettes, coffee, sugar, salt, milk and oil

loans.name: Kousar

texts.en:
Kousar is 53-year-old lady living with her spouse and eight children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. She is a responsible mother. Her children have reached the age of marriage. She wants to create some savings for the marriages of her children, but it seems impossible in the absence of a profitable source of income.

Kousar's three sons have been driving auto rickshaws for many years; their income is sufficient to feed the entire family. One of her son’s has to maintain the auto rickshaw body but he does not have a sufficient amount of funds to fix the problems. Therefore, Kousar requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner, BRAC Pakistan, so that her son would be able to buy an auto rickshaw body.

She hopes that she will be able to save enough money until the time of the marriages. She thanks Kiva and the field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy an auto rickshaw body.

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en:
Members of this group requested to remain anonymous on the Kiva website.

One of the members is a 37-year-old married Iraqi woman. She is a mother of two children. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, she is one of the many Iraqi woman who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.

She started her small, home-based sewing business activity 10 years ago, and as an experienced seamstress she is constantly looking for opportunities to improve the services so she can provide and generate more income. Her work is many times interrupted by power cuts that are frequent in her area. To overcome this challenge and be able to manage her work and time better she would like to buy a small generator and also a new sewing machine. To be able to afford the purchases she is taking a group loan from Relief International - Microfinance Iraq. 

Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor--thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of three to five clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group.

Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator and a new sewing machine

loans.name: Boni Banura

texts.en:
Boni Banura is 48 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the region of Fort Portal in Uganda. She is married and has five children. For the past six years, Boni Banura has been working hard to manage her tea business, which deals in providing tea services. 

To help expand her business, Boni Banura has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new items for the tea business, and will help Boni Banura to generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her family . Boni Banura hopes that in the future she will be able to have a good income and build rental houses. 

Boni Banura is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Boni Banura who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more new items for the tea business

loans.name: Mable

texts.en:
Mable is 34 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the region of Kampala north in Uganda. She is married and has 3 children with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 7 years, Mable has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, which sells chicken. 

To help expand her business, Mable has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens for the farm, and will help Mable to generate greater profits and growth in business. Mable hopes that in the future she will be able to expand the her business into a bigger farm. 

Mable is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mable who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens for her farm

loans.name: Ana Silvia

texts.es: Ana de 36 años de edad vive en casa propia con su hija y su esposo quien trabaja de motorista, ella posee un negocio de venta de papas fritas desde hace 8 años en su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ganancias y con la ayuda de su esposo logran solventar  algunos gastos de su hogar, Ana está solicitando un crédito para la compra de papas por mayor y así poder seguir con su negocio ya que esa es su única fuente de trabajo y poder tener una mejor calidad de vida junto con su familia.
texts.en:
Ana, 36, lives in her own home with her daughter and her husband, who works as a driver.  She's had a business selling French fries from her home for 8 years.  With this business she gets earnings that enable her to help her husband to cover the household expenses.  

Ana is requesting a loan to buy potatoes at wholesale.  This way, she can continue with her business, because this is her only source of work, so that she can have a better quality of life with her family.

loans.use: to buy potatoes at wholesale

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the region of Mukono in Uganda. She is married and has four children who are all currently in school. For the past 10 years, Victor has been working hard to manage her business selling household items, which specializes in kitchen items. 

To help expand her business, Victor has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings (UGX) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more items and will help Victor generate greater profits and business expansion. Victor hopes that in the future she will be able to produce quality products. 

Victor is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Victor who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Yulchiboy

texts.ru: Юлчибою 19 лет. Он молодой, целеустремленный и честный человек. Юлчибой не женат, и живет с родителями. Он в средней школе учился отлично и после окончания средней школы он поступил в Горно - Металлургический Университет Таджикистана. Он учится на втором курсе. Юлчибой является одним из успешных студентов. Он также активно участвует в общественных мероприятиях университета. Юлчибой должен оплатить за учебный договор. Он запрашивает займ для оплаты учебы в университете. Он надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en: Yulchiboy is 19 years old. He is a purposeful and honest young man. Yulchiboy is not married and lives with his parents. He studied in high school excellently and after graduating enrolled in the Mining - Metallurgical University of Tajkistan. He is in the second year. Yulchiboy is one of the successful students. He is also actively involved in university public events. Yulchiboy must pay for the training contract. He is requesting a loan to pay for university studies. He hopes for your generosity.

loans.use: To pay for education

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman. She has six children, all of whom attend school and one who is underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mejumaa operates a cashew nut selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is married with three school-age children. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

Salama has operated a cashew nut selling business for the past three years. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the 30,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase more sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Mesaidi

texts.en:
Mesaidi is a married woman with five children who attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Mesaidi has operated a charcoal-selling business for the past five years. Her potential clients are neighbors and passersby. She cites transportation costs as her major challenge.

With the KSHS 25,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal and firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal and firewood for resale.

loans.name: Musu

texts.en:
Musu is 20 years old and lives in Kakata. She is single and did not attend school.  She has two children ages 1 and 5, and both of them attend school.

For the past two years, she has been selling red oil and cosmetics in the local market. She enjoys her business because she has a lot of customers, and the profit she generates helps her buy food for her family.

She is requesting a loan to purchase red oil and cosmetics for her business. She plans to build a house and send her children to school in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase red oil and cosmetics for her business

loans.name: Massah

texts.en:
Massah is 39 years old and lives in Kakata Town. Her spouse is a driver and they have 3 children between 6 to 12 years who are in school and live at home. Massah did go to school.

She received a little income from her husband to start her business. She has been cooking and selling rice and soup for 3 years now, and she enjoys the flow of her customers since she is the only one who sells rice, bitter ball (an eggplant-like vegetable), etc., in her community.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more fish, meat, bitter ball, okra, pepper, rice, and oil for her business. Her dream is to become a house owner and  see her children in collage in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more fish, meat, bitter ball, okra, pepper, rice, and oil for her business

loans.name: Gohar

texts.en:
Gohar lives in Vanadzor town with her mother. After graduating university Gohar started to work at a local school. Together with work at school, Gohar has been also providing trainings for her students. Despite her young age, Gohar is skilled and educated enough to be able to provide high-quality trainings. Now, for creating more efficient conditions for her and her students, Gohar wants to purchase notebooks. She asks for this loan for purchasing the notebooks and being able to provide better quality trainings. 

Gohar has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan is very important for this young teacher to be able to improve the teaching method. 

Gohar is the only breadwinner of the family, and the income from teaching is very important for her and her mother.

loans.use: to pay for notebooks for providing trainings to children

loans.name: Margalita

texts.en:
Margalita is 57 years old. She lives in a small village of Lashe with her husband and granddaughter. The family runs a small-scale agricultural business with three milk cows and two calves. During grazing season, when the cows milk well, Margalita makes cheese that she sells from her house. The family faces poverty and gets small-sized social assistance from the government to cover food expenses.
With the received credit, Margalita will start a pig farm. She will purchase two pigs and feed for them. After five or six months, Margalita will have piglets for sale. She will sell the piglets in the village as well as at the local open market. The living conditions of the family will significantly improve and, in the future, they will have enough income to access regular credit products that are available on the country’s capital market. This will enable them to further expand the family farm.

loans.use: to start a pig farm

loans.name: Aren

texts.en:
Aren is from Vanadzor town where he lives with his mother. Aren's brother currently serves in the army and his father is a migrant worker in Russia. So, Aren, as the only man in the family, feels very responsible to provide his mother with good living conditions. Aren has been working in the construction trade for five years. He receives orders from local people who value his hard and tireless work. Now, this hard-working young man needs financial support to be able to increase his working capital and receive more orders. Aren needs this loan to purchase tools and materials for providing construction services. He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan is very important for Aren to be able to have new tools and materials and provide better service to his clients.
Aren waits for your support.

loans.use: to pay for tools and materials for providing construction services

loans.name: Jumabubu

texts.ru: Жумабубу 55 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитали 6 детей. Дети все женаты и самостоятельно проживают. С Жумабубу проживает средний сын с супругой и детьми. Младший сын с супругой находится на заработках в Казахстане. У Жумабубу - среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Жумабубу занимается животноводством, стартовав 12 лет назад, с покупки скота на 20,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Жумабубу, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 дойная корова, 5 лошадей, 20 овец. Ежемесячный доход составляет 12,000 сом (KGS). Супруг активно помогает по хозяйству. Каждый день с утра уходит на выпас своего скота, Жумабубу, в это время убирает в хлеву, меняет воду, заготавливает сено. Работу делают дружно. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Жумабубу обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом на покупку еще одной лошади для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Жумабубу планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на дальнейшее обучение своих внуков.
texts.en: Jumabubu is 55 years old, married and has raised six children with her husband. All of her children are now married and live independently, except for the middle son, who lives in Jumabubu's house together with his wife and kids. Her youngest son and his wife are working in Kasahstan. Jumabubu has a high school diploma and raises livestock, which is the main source of income for her family. The livestock business was started 12 years ago with 20,000 som (KGS). Due to Jumabubu's diligent work, her herd has now expanded to: one milk cow, 5 horses and 20 sheep, and the animals provide the family with 12,000 som (KGS) monthly profit. Jumabubu's husband actively helps her with the livestock. Every morning he takes the animals out to pasture, while Jumabubu cleans out the barn, changes water and puts up hey. The two work happily together. In order to further expand the herd Jumabubu has applied for a loan to micro-finance bank "Bai-Tushum and Partners" to finance the purchase of another horse. She plans to continue investing the profits from the loan into the livestock business, continue expanding her herd and save money to help pay for the education of her grandchildren.

loans.use: to buy a horse

loans.name: Elmira

texts.ru: Эльмире 48 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 4 детей. У Эльмиры - средне-специальное образование, окончила курсы секретаря-машинистки и дополнительно отучилась в торговом колледже по специальности продавец. Некоторое время работала секретарем в разных организациях, но выйдя замуж, оставила работу и занялась ведением хозяйства и постепенно воспитанием семьи. Семья у Эльмиры большая: 2 сына и 2 дочери, все дети кроме младшего сына женаты и замужем и проживают отдельно. Только младший сын живет с родителями и активно помогает Эльмире по хозяйству. Супруг занимается услугами предоставления пассажирских услуг населению. В качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Эльмира занимается животноводством и полеводством, стартовав 21 год назад, с покупки скота на 3,500 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Эльмиры, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 1 дойная корова, 1 теленок, 2 лошади, 15 овец, 25 индюков, 30 кур, а также обрабатывают земельный надел мерою 3,60 ГА, на котором выращивают фасоль, картофель и многолетнюю траву. Также дополнительным доходом является то, что Эльмира в зимний сезон реализует молоко из дому. Ежемесячный совокупный доход составляет 9,500 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Эльмира обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом- на покупку бычков для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Эльмира планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на покупку нового дома для сына.
texts.en: Elmira is 48 years old, married and has raised four children with her husband. She has a professional degree as an administrative assistant and typist and also received a retail associate certificate from a business college. For a while Elmira worked as a secretary for various organizations, but when she married she stopped working, focusing on managing the household and raising her children. Elmira has a large family: two sons and two daughters. The kids, with the exception of the youngest son, are married and live separately. The youngest son still lives with his parents and actively helps them with the household. Elmira's husband is a taxi driver and the main income for the family comes from their livestock herd. The family farm was started 21 years ago with 3,500 som (KGS) and has now expanded to include: one milk cow, one calf, two horses, 15 sheep, 25 turkeys, 30 chickens and 8.8 acres of land where the family grows beans, potatoes and hay. During winter, Elmira also sells the milk from her cow and horses, generating additional income. The monthly income from the farm is 9,500 som (KGS). In order to further expand the livestock business, Elmira has turned to the micro-finance bank "Bai-Tushum and Partners" for a loan. She plans to use the loan to buy a steer for the herd. Elmira will use profits from this expansion to buy more animals and eventually save enough money to build a house for her son.

loans.use: to buy steers

loans.name: Chris' Group

texts.en:
33 year old Chris has 4 children and lives in Ilali village in Vihiga in Kenya. Ilali village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Chris and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Chris works as a subsistence farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Chris and other promoters in his community (including: Betty, Boniface, Absalom and Mercyline) need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Chris will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. He wants to be a promoter because he wants to be a steward of development. He finds it an achievement when his community can access safe water. Chris believes that with the dispenser there will be no more suffering with waterborne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Chris’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
In Lukose village in Vihiga, Kenya, Elizabeth has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Elizabeth is a hardworking trustworthy well-known well-liked member of the community with 3 children. She lives with her family in a house made of concrete walls, concrete floor, and an iron roof.

Lukose village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Elizabeth and the 16 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Elizabeth has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Elizabeth volunteered to be the promoter because she believes it is good to assist others and she wants to help the community to fight germs that cause waterborne diseases. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Grace, Sarah and Pauline.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Elizabeth’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Geofrey

texts.en:
Geofrey, 47, is a resident of Rwabarata in the Kiruhura district. He dropped out of school upon the death of his father, which left him with no means to raise fees for his education. 

Pushed by the need to support his aging mother and young siblings as the elder son in the home, he settled at their home and started serious banana farming. This business grew and helped him to sustain his father’s family and support the education of his young brothers. 

He later obtained a loan of 2,000,000 from Ugafode, which has helped him to prosper and made their family stable.  

He is requesting a loan of 5,000,000 UGX to help him rehabilitate their residential house to make it more habitable.

loans.use: To renovate his residential house.

loans.name: Sanaa's Group

texts.en:
Sanaa is a 42-year-old woman. She is a widow and is raising her six children on her own since the death of her husband – with assistance from her family. 


With limited career options, due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Sanaa is one of the many Iraqi woman who is working from home, using her sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of her family.


She started her small, home-based sewing business activity ten years ago, and as an experienced seamstress, she is constantly looking for opportunities to improve the services she can provide and generate more income. Her work is many times interrupted by power cuts frequent in her area. 

To overcome this challenge and be able to manage her work and time better, she would like to buy a small generator and also a new sewing machine. To be able to afford the purchases, she is taking a group loan from Relief International Microfinance Iraq. 


Relief International - Microfinance Iraq offers "group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of 3 to 5 clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group.


Based on the political and social challenges of lending in Iraq, personally identifiable information about this borrower has been altered for their protection. RI-Iraq appreciates Kiva lenders' consideration of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Iraqi borrowers.

loans.use: to buy a small generator and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Celestina's E. Group

texts.en:
This group is made up of four enterprising women. One of them is Celestina E., a 36-year-old married woman with three children. For the past seven years, her business has been the sale of cooking oil, soap and noodles. She distributes these items to her retail customers in her community. She requests the loan in order to purchase more cooking oil, soap and noodles from the factory so that she can distribute them to her customers.

Gladys is a 34 year old woman and her business is the sale of drinks. Beatrice is a 50 year old woman and her business is the sale of provisions. Finally, Celestina Z, is 35 years old and her business is the sale of drinks.

loans.use: to purchase more cooking oil, soap and noodles from the factory to distribute to customers.

loans.name: Gormah

texts.en: Gormah lives in Kakata Town.  She is 37 years old and has 5 children between the ages of 6 months and 17 years old.   They live at home and four of her children attend school. For the past six years, she has run a table where she sells fresh fish, rice, pepper, etc. in the local market. She started this business with her mother's help and learned this way of selling from her friends.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more  fresh fish, rice, pepper, etc. for her business. Her plan is to buy a piece of land  and build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more  fresh fish, rice, pepper, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Balentin De Jesus

texts.es: Balentin de 61 años de edad, el se dedica  a la venta y cría de cerdos, el negocio está ubicado en la zona rural, por lo que cuenta con un lugar muy apto para este tipo de trabajo, Balentin es una persona muy responsable y trabajador vive con su esposa en casa propia, Desde hace 33 años que se dedica a este trabajo, el cual ha ido creciendo poco a poco, a pesar de esto él cuenta con una cantidad de clientes muy aceptable, por lo que desea contar con mayor cantidad de cerdos para extender aún más su negocio, es por esto que él solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda invertir comprando: concentrado para cerdos, vitaminas, y así mismo mejorar el lugar en el cual habitan sus crías, de manera que el estándar de calidad sea aún más alto y así brindar un mejor servicio, el cual le permita mejorar sus ganancias y poder tener unaejor calidad de vida junto con su esposa.
texts.en:
Balentin, 61, makes his living selling and raising pigs. The business is located in the rural zone; therefore he has a very apt place for this kind of work. Balentin is a very responsible and hardworking person who lives with his wife in his own house. 33 years ago, he started this work, which he has grown bit by bit. Despite this he has a very acceptable quantity of customers, therefore he wishes do have a higher quantity of pigs to extend his business even more. 

For this reason he is applying for a loan whereby he can invest, buying: pig feed, vitamins and at the same time improve the place in which the piglets live. In this manner the standard of quality will be even higher and thereby he will give a better service, which will allow him to improve his income and be able to have a better quality of life along with his wife.

loans.use: to buy vitamins and feed for the pigs and improve the place where he maintains them.

loans.name: Blanca Estela

texts.es: Blanca de 34 años, posee una tienda desde hace 6 años donde vende artículos de primera necesidad, frijoles, leche, huevos, pan, entre otros, está ubicada en el lugar de su residencia en una localidad muy transitada, se ha hecho de mucha clientela, pues tiene la tienda mas surtida, con productos de calidad, a precios accesibles y con un servicio inigualable siempre a la orden de los clientes, ella quiere acrecentar el negocio y realizar una nueva inversión pero necesita de capital por eso le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar granos básicos, golosinas, huevos, pan, bebidas, etc. Blanca asegura que cancelara la deuda y a la vez confía en que le dará a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Blanca, 34, has owned a store for 6 years.  In her store, she sells a variety of basic consumer goods such as: beans, milk, bread, and other items.  Her store is located in her home, in an area where there are many passers-by.  She has many customers, because her store is well-stocked with quality products at affordable prices, and she always provides unparalleled service to her customers.  She wants to expand the business and make a new investment, but she needs capital.  This is why she is requesting a loan from INTEGRAL to buy staple consumer products, snacks, eggs, bread, drinks, etc.  

Blanca is certain that she will pay off the debt, and she trusts that with this loan she will be able to give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy staple consumer goods, snacks, eggs, bread, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Maud

texts.en:
Maud is 45 years old and lives in the town of Ntungamo in the region of fortportal in Uganda. She is Married and has six children, four of them are currently in school. For the past four years, Maud has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells home products and food stuff. 

To help expand her business, Maud has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Uganda Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more stock of food stuff and home products for the business, which will help Maud generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Maud hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business. 

Maud is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Maud who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of food stuff and home products for the business,

loans.name: Chirine

texts.en:
Chirine is a 29-year-old married mother of two children who has been running her own convenience store for eight months.

Chirine used to work as a teacher, but when she gave birth to her newborn baby few months ago, she stopped working to take care of her precious children.

She thought of starting her own business to make sure that she can still support her husband and improve their living. She opened a convenience store at the same building she is living in, which is very suitable to take care of both her family's needs and business development.

Chirine is acquiring a youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise with special offer products that will attract new customers and increase her selling and income.

Chirine is working hard to keep on developing and expanding her business in a well managed way.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise with special offer products

loans.name: Dúo Cristo Libertador Group

texts.es:
Duo Cristo Libertador
Doña Elba Araceli es originaria de Tecpan, Guatemala tiene 35 años de edad bajo su responsabilidad esta su hijo de 3 años de edad, ella se dedica a la elaboración de tejidos a mano y a la venta de medicinas naturales.
El crédito que ella recibió le sirvió para invertirlo en sus tejidos y en la venta de medicinas.
El sueño de ella es ampliar mas su negocio ofrecer variedad de productos  a su clientela para obtener mejores ganancias y mandar a su hijos a la escuela,  esperando que ustedes nuevamente le puedan ayudar con el credito solicitado.
texts.en:
Duo Cristo Libertador (Duo Christ Liberator)

Elba Araceli is from Tecpan, Guatemala. She is 35 years old and takes care of her three-year-old son. She makes hand-woven products and sells natural medicine.

The loan that she received was used to invest in knitting and in the sale of medicines.

Her dream is to expand her business offering a variety of products to her clients to gain better profits and to send her children to school. She is hoping that you can help her again with this loan.

loans.use: to purchase natural medicines and raw materials to make typical knit products.

loans.name: Ciriaca

texts.en:
Ciriaca is a married woman and a mother of six children from Talibon, Bohol, Philippines. She earns a living through her sari-sari or retail business, selling various goods and items to the people in her place. Ciriaca has been in the business for several years now. This is the source of her income.

Ciriaca is asking for a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, candies, soda, beverages, soap, toiletries, biscuits and snack foods. With this loan, she will be able to improve the variety of her stock, thus attracting more buyers in her store.

In the future, Ciriaca hopes of making her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for future use.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to sell like canned goods, candies, soda, beverages, soap, toiletries, biscuits and snack foods

loans.name: Abdukodir

texts.ru: Абдукодиру 40 лет. Он женат и имеет 3 детей. Абдукодир живет в сельской местности. Основным источником дохода семьи является земледелие и животноводство. Он более 20 лет занимается скотоводством. Он откармливает как крупно-рогатого скота так и мелко-рогатого скота. Абдукодир имеет дополнительный доход от выращивания сельхоз культур как пшеница и картофель. Он является владельцем бизнеса. Его жена помогает ему введению бизнеса. Абдукодир хочет увеличить оборотный капитал и развевать бизнес дальше. Абдукодир запрашивает займ на сумму 10000 сомони для покупки скота. Он ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Abdukodir is 40 years old, married, and has three children. He lives in a rural area and his main source of income is agriculture and livestock. He has more than 20 years of experience raising cattle, sheep, and goats. He earns additional income planting crops such as wheat and potatoes. Abdukodir runs the business with his wife's help. He wants to increase his working capital and continue to expand, so he has requested a loan of 10,000 somoni to buy cattle. He awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy cattle and expand his business

loans.name: Maria Emerita

texts.es:
María, es casada, tiene 3 hijos, vive junto a ellos y los tiene estudiando, es una persona muy dedicada al cuido de su familia  y a atender bien su negocio, su actividad económica es venta de pupusas y ropa nueva, aprendió de su familia el oficio, hoy en día ya tiene tres años de experiencia en su negocio, por el momento no ha tenido ninguna dificultad en realizar esta actividad.
Invertirá en la compra de harina, chicharrón, quesillo, aceite, y variedad de ropa, sabe que contando con los productos necesarios para elaborar pupusas y surtir con diferentes estilos, colores y tallas su negocio podrá llenar las expectativas de sus clientes, tendrá ventas mayores, atraerá a más clientes, ingresos mejores con los que podrá cancelar la deuda y seguir cubriendo los gastos familiares.
Sueña con tener un negocio más rentable, que le dé la oportunidad de ampliar su casa, darles educación superior a sus hijos.
texts.en:
María is married, has 3 children, lives with them and has them in school. She is a person who is very dedicated to caring for her family and caring well for her business. Her economic activity is the sale of pupusas [fried tortillas stuffed with cheese] and new clothes. She learned the trade from her family. Now she already has three years of experience in her business. For the moment she has not had any difficulties in carrying out this activity.

She will invest in the purchase of flour, fried pork rinds, cheese, oil and a variety of clothing. She knows that by having the necessary products to make pupusas and stock different styles, colors and sizes, her business will be able to fulfill the expectations of her customers, she will have more sales, attract more customers, higher profits with which she will be able to pay off the debt and continue covering family expenses.

She dreams of having a more profitable business, which will give her the opportunity to expand her house and give a higher education to her children.

loans.use: to buy flour, fried pork rinds, cheese, oil and a variety of clothing.

loans.name: Aileen

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Aileen works hard to support her family.

She has a tricycle transportation business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from fish vending. Aileen is borrowing 7,000 PHP  through NWTF in order to buy spare parts for her tricycle transportation.

Aileen has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

loans.name: Kimutai

texts.en:
Kimutai is a farmer from the highlands of Kericho, a very rich area for agriculture. He is married and has three children. He has been a farmer for five years. He produces and sells milk, eggs, and tea, which is the major income-generating crop in Kenya. He chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because he has seen other farmers do well with the loans, and that they help small farmers grow their business.
This loan will enable him buy a chaff cutter for preparing feed for his dairy cows.This will help the cows produce more milk for sale and thus bring in more income. Kimutai says that this loan will improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase a chaff cutter.

loans.name: Kiprotich

texts.en: Meet Kiprotich, a 27 year old farmer who resides in Kericho in the south rift area of Kenya. He has been a farmer for three years. Like most residents of Kericho, Kiprotich produces and sells milk and tea. Though he is a young farmer, he loves every aspect of mixed farming. The main challenge he faces is the lack of sufficient capital. Kiprotich chose Juhudi Kilimo to fund him because he wants to grow his business and achieve his dreams. During the training he received, Kiprotich learnt that he should develop a lifestyle of saving. Kiprotich will use the loan to purchase poultry, which will increase his income.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Terry's Group

texts.en:
Terry lives in Matrini B village in Vihiga, Kenya with her family. She has no children but is planning to start a family soon. The community of Matrini B village collects their drinking water from a municipal water supply because there is no piped water supply in this part of Vihiga Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Matrini B’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Matrini B, 20 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water. Terry has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. Two other volunteer promoters (Gladys and Ronald) from the surrounding community are part of this group loan.

Matrini B village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Terry believes that the dispenser will provide safe water which will improve health and help prevent diseases. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Terry’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: to provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Tulibamu Group

texts.en:
Josephine, aged 39 years, is married with three children, who are 12, 10 and 11 years old. All of them attend school, and Josephine is in charge of providing school fees. She supplies fresh foods as her major source of income, and has been doing this business since 2000.


Josephine borrowed UGX 500,000 from UGAFODE so that she can expand her business. Now she has applied for an additional UGX 1,000,000 to buy more stock for her business and also buy a piece of land.


She dreams of buying a vehicle that can help her in supplying her items to her customers. She believes this will soon come true with the help of UGAFODE’s low interest rate loans. 


Her major challenges are limited capital and price fluctuations.

loans.use: to buy vegetables for her business and also buy a piece of land.

loans.name: Varujan

texts.en:
Varujan is from Spitak town where he lives with his wife (in the photo). He has worked as a taxi driver for 10 years, driving his own car. Varujan is a very enthusiastic and hard-working driver and has a lot of loyal customers. Unfortunately the car that Varujan drives is currently damaged and he isn't able to continue his taxi business. 
Varujan asks for this loan to be able to renovate the car and purchase new tires. He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. This loan will greatly assist Varujan to continue his taxi business and he will be able to earn income for his family.

loans.use: to pay for renovation of the car and purchase new tires

loans.name: Al-Zahor Group

texts.en: Al-Zahor Group is a four-member group. All of the members are poor women from Hadramout, Yemen. Collectively, they applied for a YER 150,000 loan from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank (AMB) to renovate their houses. Zahra is a 42-year-old married woman and has children. She is the leader of the group. She is uneducated and lives in a poor area in Hadramout. Her house is very old and in a miserable situation. She has accumulated some money to renovate her house. It is known that house renovation requires a lot of money. She has started renovating her house, but now she is short of money. She needs to complete the renovation task, so she asked for a loan to buy cement and carpentry materials. She hopes that after the completion of the house renovation, she can start accumulating money to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy cement and carpentry materials to renovate her house.

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en: Anahit is from Sisian town. She has been involved in the clothing retail business for many years. Anahit purchases clothing from the city market and resells it in neighboring villages. The income from this activity helps Anahit to sustain her living. Now by applying for this loan, Anahit asks for financial support to purchase a new stock of clothing. She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan will greatly assist Anahit to continue her business and she will be very grateful to all her lenders for their support.

loans.use: to pay for a new stock of clothing to sell

loans.name: Tamriko

texts.en: Tamriko is 24-year-old married woman. She lives with her husband in Tbilisi, the capital city of Georgia. Her husband works at the car wash and earns 400 GEL per month. Tamriko is currently unemployed. She decided to start her own business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of $1000 to begin a trading business. With this credit, she plans to purchase household goods to resell and increase the income of her family. The Start Up program will be a great support for her family.

loans.use: to purchase household goods to resell.

loans.name: Gulshan

texts.ru: Гулшан 33 года, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 4 детей, 2 детей школьники, 2 - дошкольники. Самому младшему сыну нет еще и года. У Гулшан - среднее образование, она домохозяйка, воспитывает детей и ведет свое небольшое хозяйство. В качестве основного дохода для своей семьи Гулшан занимается животноводством и полеводством, стартовав 13 лет назад, с покупки скота на 10,000 сом KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Гулшан, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день имеется: 2 дойные коровы, 2 теленка, 10 кур, а также имеет земельный надел мерою 1,20 ГА на котором выращивает картофель и фасоль. Супруг Гульшан занимается перевозкой пассажиров, а также подрабатывает в механиком в станции технического обслуживания. Дети маленьки, нужно ставить их на ноги, поэтому муж активно работает и помогает своей семье. Ежемесячный совокупный доход составляет 10,000 сом (KGS). В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Гулшан обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом-на покупку коровы для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Гулшан планирует вложить в дальнейшее приумножение количества домашней скотины, и планирует накопить средства на дальнейшее обучение детей.
texts.en: Gulshan is 33 years old and is raising four children with her husband. Two of her kids are school age and two are still babies. Her youngest son isn't even one year old yet. Gulshan has a high school degree, she is a home maker and raises her children, as well as takes care of her small farm. The farm is the main source of income for the family and was started 13 years ago with the 10,000 som (KGS).
